text:
So I was at GDC, I saw the announcement, I
went to their boot and tried it and this is
a much bigger deal than I expected.

Is this thing the next big thing in gaming
for sure?

You read the title, you kinda now were this
is going.

I am very excited about the potential this
holds, but I also have concerns and worries.

For those still unfamiliar with what the heck
is going on, Google announced Stadia, a gaming

cloud gaming platform that promises to run
games on almost any PC, Smart TV or phone

by running the game on a server and streaming
the video footage to your screen over the
internet.

The promise is smooth and instant gaming on
any internet connected device.

That part does not impress me very much and
if you have been following this channel for

a while it probably does not impress you as
well.

There a variety of existing niche services
that already do this and I have explored a
lot of them in previous videos.
Some of them really, really well.
Nvidia even has one!

It is still in beta testing for pc but if
you have a beta key it works… and yet Google

does a number of things differently to all
those attempts.

So after talking to some of the people in
Google booth and trying this for myself and

talking to a lot of developers there are some
of things about this service that sound and
feel very good, some of it... does not.

So let us discuss some of the most notorious
elements in a convenient YouTube-friendly
format.

Let's start with what I like: lots of progress
on reducing parts of the latency

The big Aquiles heel of this concept is always
latency.

Since the game footage has to get to you and
the controller inputs have to get from you

to the server it is inevitable that there
is always going be an extra latency from input
to action on cloud gaming.

This latency is always going to depend on
mainly 3 elements:

-Encoding overhead, or the amount of time
it takes to encode and decode the video feed
or the controller inputs.

-Physical distance from the server running
the game

-The quality of the internet infrastructure
in general, especially the part that is closer
to the final user.

Google has been putting lots of resources
for improving the encoding and transmission
techniques.

They already have tons of experience in video
transmission from things like YouTube.

There is a TON of technology they are developing
for not just improving the base latency but

in general improving the feel of the quality
of the service on a variety of different connections.

One of the first game developers they are
working with is Id Games and as explained

on a talk by id developer Dustin Land at GDC
they wanted to use the extreme speed and motion

of Doom as a test to make sure the experience
would work even on the most intense games.

Heck, the one piece of hardware they announced
is a controller, one that connects directly

to wifi rather than a PC or TV in order to
remove one step in the process of getting

those input to the server which is part of
that larger effort to reduce latency.

Google also already has an enormous number
of server farms worldwide which makes them

one of the few companies that can really provide
servers that are close enough to a lot of
people to be able to do this effectively.
And the third point... well.

The worrisome: the last line of the connection
still kinda sucks!

Google uses very ambitious language for Stadia
and the number of people they want to reach,

but even in developed countries like the ones
in the launch list the internet conditions
might not be enough for this to become mainstream.

Consider the following I tried a good chunk
of the GDC Stadia demo running on a Chrome
book.

Some of the sessions by google commented that
these demos were running in a server about
50 miles away

but this being a convention demo it is fair
to say Google put some care that the connection

was good so this is as ideal as the test circumstances
get and the latency hit was similar to what
I get using Shadow at home

and any artifact as a result of video the
compression was very similar as well.
This is a good thing, it is very manageable.

But later that day I saw the first live demo
of Doom Eternal running on Stadia, again under

ideal conditions and there were a fair number
of frame skips.

How will this do with someone who does not
have fiber internet?
Heck, what about data consumption?

I talked to a lot of people on GDC and the
dominant topic was Data Caps.

Even in Google's home turf on the US a lot
of people have connections with Data limits

that might not make them possible to use sometimes
like this currently, which means that Google

might have to do a lot of political work just
for this to pick up a critical user base on
its home country.

And on the sessions on GDC google made it
clear that they are working on technological

solutions that would make this work well on
a variety of connections.

But I am not sure if this is something that
they can do much without a strong improvement
in global internet infrastructure.
I might be wrong.

This is a chicken an egg problem in the sense
that this might create demand for better internet

but not enough people might use this because
of lack of better internet.
In fact they have not

yet disclosed any minimum connection requirements
for this thing but given the requirements
of existing services well, it might be hard.
But that leads to:
The bad: the first line of release countries.

Oh yes, if you know me you knew I was going
to bring this up.

One of the big points in the marketing message
of this service is how it can open the world
of gaming to tons of new users.

Some of the faster-growing gaming markets
were consoles are not good options are countries

where Google might have the data centers to
pulls this off, but are not included in the
initial release.
Where is India?

Were is South America?It might get there if
the service is successful (this might be a

test run)... but can the service be successful
in the first place when all these countries
already have a lot of good cheap local options?
Not sure.

The Worrisome: this is an entirely new platform
to develop for.

I am going to be honest: I expected Stadia
to be games running on PC and being streamed
back, like Parsec or Shadow.
It is not.

It is based on Linux (the Ubuntu kernel in
fact according to the GDC talks) with an undisclosed

custom CPU and a custom AMD GPU but it does
not immediately run any existing game, the

developer most port their games to Stadia
which again Dustin Land from id games described

as something between the dev process of a
PC and a console at the GDC session I attended.

Side note: since the OS of Stadia is Linux
Dustin Land did comment that the first

step of porting a game there was to make a
Linux version and for testing, they had a

2016 Doom version running on Ubuntu but fully
acknowledged that Linux desktop adoption is

not nearly big enough for this to be something
other than a Stadia demo.

I have expressed before the ideological reasons
why I would like gaming on Linux to pick up

speed and it is killing me that there is a
Doom and Doom ethernal Linux executable somewhere

in an id games server that we will never play
with.
Ok.
Side not over.

Back to the issue at hand, Stadia is like
an entirely new console starting from zero
rather than a PC.

From the developer perspective, that means
yet another platform to port and test games,

which requires money and time investments
and might mean that a lot of games might not
be available ever.

From a consumer perspective, it means that
there might be difficult to justify buying

on this thing when there are few games on
it.
Another worrisome thing: YouTube integration.
The idea on paper is really cool.

Games will have the ability to integrate chat
actions while a creator stream so all your

incessant spamming will finally actually do
something
(please stop spamming my chat).

Will new games go through the pain of implementing
this on existing games when it is a feature
unique to the service?
No idea.
Might take a while.

And there is also stuff like viewers having
the option to immediately start playing a
game if they see it on a video.
Hey, you know what kinda sucks right now?
YouTube monetization.
Do you know what would be interesting?

What if donations from viewers allow people
to affect the game or that if someone starts

playing a game after seeing your video the
creator gets a tiny bit of the money of the
interaction.

Evidently, I am all up for ideas on better
ways to monetizing content that is not purely
advertising.

I am kinda annoyed that they have not provided
more details on how this is going to work
to any youtuber,
except for matpat apparently.

But given how often YouTube introduces a new
feature which has... unexpected effects I

can't help but be a bit skeptical of how this
is going to be implemented.
The Bad: Where is the pricing?

Not only do we not know how much this is going
to cost but there is no mention of the overall
pricing model.
Is this going to be a subscription service?
Do you have to buy games?
Both?
How is revenue going to be shared with developers?
Running a cloud gaming service is expensive.

This is why existing services like Shadow
or Parsec experiment with their pricing and

if the whole selling point is making gaming
accessible to more people a high price point
would make it difficult.

There is a chance they bankroll the whole
thing and provide the service at a loss with

the hopes of creating value long term or harvesting
data (which is kinda what they did with YouTube,

or might still be doing, no one knows) which
leads perfectly to my next point.

The Worrisome: This is Google we are talking
about.

I understand this is a bit rich coming from
a creator on a Google-owned platform

but big tech companies, in general, have been
under a lot of scrutinies over the way privacy
and data harvesting is managed.

So the thought of giving another part of your
life to google completely can be a red flag
for some, even if it means a cheaper service.

We will have to wait, with so little precious
information on the actual implementation of
the system one has to wonder the following:
The Bad: Who is this for?
Who is the target consumer for this service?

With all the twitter backlash at the announcement
of the service, there is one thing that I
think we are easily forgetting.

Stadia is not meant to be a replacement for
PC Gaming and it is likely not a product for
a power user of PC Gaming, just like consoles.

A lot of the features that these power users
like from PC are not accessible from Stadia
as people like to point out,

but literally the same case can be made for
game consoles.

Now for PC gamers that only care about playing
the game with no customizations and console

gamers more interested in a plug and play
convenience experience…

Stadia starts making a bit more sense, but
a sector of those gamers are going to be too

concerned about latency or game ownership
for cloud gaming in general to make sense.

So, look at this way: Here we have the power
users that care so much about customization,

latency or game ownership that they would
never consider cloud gaming.

Here we have the people who are either in
markets or circumstances were consoles and

components are so expensive expensive who
could really use cloud gaming, but either

have bad internet, data caps or live outside
the very specific support area.

Here in the middle, we have the potential
user, who really just wants to play the game

and does not care enough to buy a dedicated
console or build a PC (Which is fine, just

enjoy your games your way) but they have internet
that is good enough and a supported country.

Who exactly is this market is... very hard
to tell and will be determined ultimately
by how this thing is priced.
Which again, we do not know.

So, look, I have tried my fair share of cloud
gaming on this channel and I dig it, I personally

use Shadow when I play on my tv out of pure
convenience even though I am not sure I am

the target consumer for it and part of me
is excited to see a big company give an early
shake at it.

I am worried about the details we are missing
for it such as the whole pricing model and

the very slim country release list or the
YouTube integration but I think it could be

transformative for a lot of people who want
to do more gaming but just do not want to
buy a console or build a PC.

Now the real question is, if that specific
crowd big enough to sustain a service this
big?

Or are the limits on internet infrastructure
on developing countries (and the US) bad enough

that it is still too early for something like
this to be more than a Niche service?
We will find out.

I am 99% sure that at best it will be another
option in the growing ecosystem of how to
play games.

I will be the first in line to try this out
when it comes out in Spain, that is for sure.

Even tough the lack of pricing makes me wonder
if this is going to be too expensive for me.

You know which service streaming is not too
expensive?
Curiosity Stream!

No, seriously, it is like $3 a month for some
of the coolest content out there.

Curiosity Stream is this video’s sponsor
and a superb streaming service for documentaries

and over 2400 pieces of content for all sorts
of topics.

For example I keep complaining that the biggest
barrier for Google Stadia is internet infrastructure
and yet it might just be a matter of time.

This documentary on the birth of the internet
shows how we used technology that was meant

to create communications over nuclear attacks
and a network of connected universities to
basically create

something that is robust enough to Stream
documentaries or download games, which by the way you can do on
on your PC, Phone or TV!

Also if you want to support LowSpecGamer you
can use curiositystream.com/lowspecgamer or

the code lowspecgamer to get the first 30
days free.

Thank you to them for sponsoring this video
and you for watching.
